reviews.text:
Any Indian who sings paean about paella is lying. Because India is a land of 6000 rice varieties, about 119 rice recipes and salt. Now, imagine the task of impressing taste buds who have danced with that many rice recipes slow cooked in Indian spices with a paella. But one doesn't have to go to Racó del Túria just for their paella, one can indulge in their wine, their house-made wafers, their bread and their desserts, which - by the way - were just heavenly. Plus the atmosphere on a laid back Saturday afternoon in beautiful Valencia made the whole experience, well... wholesome.
It's one of those places one should not miss, even if one comes from India.

We went here on the recommendation of our hotel, and from talking to some other guests it seems that quite a few hotels recommend this restaurant.  We wanted to try the paella and enjoyed that, as well as the croquettes and a sweet potato dessert.

Service was initially good but then tailed off a bit as they got busier before improving again.

Be aware that some of the paella dishes need to be ordered in advance.

Overall we were pleased with our decision to eat here and enjoyed our evening.

This was supposed to be one of the best Paella restaurants in Valencia. Reservations required, the need to order certain dishes in advance. We did it all and were disappointed with both of our Paella dishes. The ambiance was nice, and they had a good wine list, this just did not make up for the quality of the food.
Everything was perfect from start to finish. Great service, great paella. Highly reccommended.

A quiet and slow-paced restaurant within the La Gran Via district, the food here is of excellent home-made quality and the surrounding outside ambiance of the neighborhood quite relaxing. The Croquetas de Jamón, Solomillo con Foie and Tarta de Chocolate were what I had, as shown in the pictures, and I recommend them all. A good choice for either a relaxed group meal or a solo experience.
